001package io.jstach.jstache;
002
003import java.lang.annotation.Documented;
004import java.lang.annotation.ElementType;
005import java.lang.annotation.Retention;
006import java.lang.annotation.RetentionPolicy;
007import java.lang.annotation.Target;
008
009/**
010 * Tag a method to be used as a mustache lambda section.
011 *
012 * Lambda sections look something like: <pre><code class="language-hbs">
013 * {{#context}}
014 * {{#lambda}}body{{/lambda}}
015 * {{/context}}
016 * </code></pre> Where in the above example a lambda is named "lambda" and optionally has
017 * access to the object called "context" and the raw body passed to the lambda is "body".
018 * A nonexhaustive example of the above lambda in Java assuming the context type is
019 * <code>SomeType</code> <em>might</em> look like:
020 *
021 * <pre><code class="language-java">
022 * &#64;JStacheLambda
023 * &#64;JStacheLambda.Raw
024 * public String lambda(SomeType context, &#64;JStacheLambda.Raw String body) {
025 *     return "Hello" + body "!";
026 * }
027 * </code> </pre>
028 *
029 * The lambda could also return a new model and use the section body as a template instead
030 * of raw content:
031 *
032 * <pre><code class="language-hbs">
033 * {{#context}}
034 * {{#lambda}}{{message}}{{/lambda}}
035 * {{/context}}
036 * </code> </pre>
037 *
038 *
039 * <pre><code class="language-java">
040 * record Model(String message){}
041 *
042 * &#64;JStacheLambda
043 * public Model lambda(SomeType context) {
044 *     return new Model("Hello " + context.name() + "!");
045 * }
046 * </code> </pre>
047 * <p>
048 * JStachio lambdas just like normal method calls do not have to be directly enclosed on
049 * the context objects but can be on implemented interfaces or inherited and thus models
050 * can be "mixed in" with interfaces to achieve sharing of lambdas. However there is
051 * currently no support for static methods to be used as lambdas.
052 * <p>
053 * JStachio lambdas work in basically two modes for <strong>parameters</strong>:
054 * <ol>
055 * <li><strong>Context aware:</strong> The default. The top of the stack is passed if an
056 * argument is present and is not annotated with {@link Raw}.
057 * <li><strong>Raw:</strong> If a string parameter is annoated with {@link Raw} it will be
058 * passed the contents of the lambda section call. <strong>Some caveats:</strong>
059 * <ul>
060 * <li><em>While this mode appears to be the default for the spec it is not for
061 * JStachio.</em></li>
062 * <li><em>The contents may not be valid mustache as the spec does not define that it has
063 * to be.</em></li>
064 * <li><em>If the lambda start tag is standalone the space and newline following the tag
065 * will not be passed to the lambda.</em></li>
066 * </ul>
067 * </ol>
068 * <p>
069 * Similarly JStachio works in two modes for <strong>return types</strong>:
070 * <ol>
071 * <li><strong>Model: </strong> The default. The returned model is pushed onto the context
072 * stack and the contents of the lambda section call are used as an inline template and
073 * rendered against it.
074 * <li><strong>Raw: </strong> If the return type is a {@link String} and the method is
075 * annotated with {@link Raw} the contents of the string are directly written
076 * <em>unescaped</em>.
077 * </ol>
078 * Regardless of parameter and return annotations the method must always be annotated with
079 * this annotation to be discovered.
080 * <p>
081 * Due to the static nature of JStachio, JStachio does not support returning
082 * <strong>truly</strong> dynamic templates which is the optional lambda spec default if a
083 * {@link String} is returned. That is you cannot construct a string as a template at
084 * runtime.
085 * <p>
086 * That being said the lambda can ostensibly return a template (and a model that the
087 * template uses) that then references the section body as a partial by using
088 * {@link #template()} and then referencing the section body with the partial named
089 * {@value #SECTION_PARTIAL_NAME}. This allows repeating or wrapping the passed in section
090 * body. In some other mustache implementations this accomplished with a render callback
091 * but because templates are compiled statically this is a powerful declaritive
092 * workaround.
093 * <p>
094 * For those that are coming from other Mustache implementations the JStachio's lambda
095 * model is very similar to the
096 * <a href="https://github.com/samskivert/jmustache">JMustache</a> model and does not have
097 * a direct analog to
098 * <a href="https://github.com/spullara/mustache.java">mustache.java</a> of returning
099 * {@code Function<String,String> } where the function will automatically be called.
100 *
101 * @see Raw
102 * @see JStacheInterfaces
103 * @author agentgt
104 *
105 */
106@Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)
107@Target(ElementType.METHOD)
108@Documented
109public @interface JStacheLambda {
110
111        /**
112         * Name of the partial to render the section body of a lambda call.
113         * @see #template()
114         */
115        public static String SECTION_PARTIAL_NAME = "@section";
116
117        /**
118         * The logical name of the lambda. If blank the method name will be used.
119         * @return lambda name
120         */
121        String name() default "";
122
123        /**
124         * An inline template used for rendering the returned model that has access to the
125         * lambda section body as a partial. The section body contents can be accessed as a
126         * partial with the name <code>&#64;section</code>. <strong>This effectively allows
127         * you render the section body and wrap or repeat it.</strong> Below is an example:
128         *
129         * <pre><code class="language-hbs">
130         * {{! template call lambda }}
131         * {{#context}}
132         * {{#lambda}}Use the force {{name}}{{/lambda}} {{! "name" will come from the returned model }}
133         * {{/context}}
134         * </code> </pre>
135         *
136         * <pre><code class="language-java">
137         * record Model(String name){}
138         *
139         * public record LambdaModel(List&lt;Model&gt; list) {
140         * }
141         *
142         * &#64;JStacheLambda(template="""
143         *      {{#list}}
144         *         {{>@section}}
145         *      {{/list}}
146         *      """)
147         * public LambdaModel lambda(SomeType context) {
148         *     return new LambdaModel(List.of(new Model("Luke"), new Model("Leia"), new Model("Anakin")));
149         * }
150         * </code> </pre>
151         *
152         * Output:
153         *
154         * <pre>
155         * Use the force Luke
156         * Use the force Leia
157         * Use the force Anakin
158         * </pre>
159         * @return the inline template and if empty is ignored. By default it is empty and
160         * ignored.
161         */
162        String template() default "";
163
164        /**
165         * Tag a method return type of String or parameter of String to be used as a raw
166         * unprocessed string.
167         * @author agentgt
168         * @see JStacheLambda
169         */
170        @Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)
171        @Target({ ElementType.PARAMETER, ElementType.METHOD })
172        @Documented
173        public @interface Raw {
174
175        }
176
177}
